newsitem.title: POLAND: Polish shares rebound, seen extending gains.
newsitem.headline: Polish shares rebound, seen extending gains.

text.p: Polish shares rose after a three-session fall and analysts said strong buying after price fixing and most stocks closing in the continuous trade above their main market's fixing signalled further growth.

The main market's WIG index rose 182.5 points, or 1.2 percent, to 16,000.6 on Friday, and trade fell 10 percent to 118.9 million zlotys ($37.2 million) on all three markets as 77 issues rose, 19 fell and nine were flat.
Analysts said, however, the market would still be under pressure from large privatisations, which might keep it locked in its over 2.5-month long horizontal trend in longer term.
"The falls were strong enough to make investors use the situation for buying...at least the beginning of the next week should be good," said Krzysztof Olszewski, an analyst at Bank Slaski brokerage.

Analysts said the undergoing sale of Poland's large Bank Handlowy, offering one-billion-zloty worth ($312 million) shares and KGHM, which in late June will offer at least 300 million-zloty ($93 million) worth shares, could hamper buying on the exchange.
They said, however, that attractiveness of investments in Poland should prevent more painful falls.
Traders were surprised with brewer Zywiec 10-percent jump and said after such unexpected growth profit-taking was likely to hit the stock in the beginning of the next week.
